page.title: 02Wybunbury Moss
page.content:
Wybunbury Moss lies a few hundred yards North of the village and is roughly oval in shape (700 yards long, 300 yards wide).It covers about 27 acres.
The moss was formed at the end of the Ice Age.Its formation was probably due to pockets of salt, brought during the Ice Age gradually being washed away. The soil above would then have collapsed leaving the hole in which the Moss was formed.
The Moss was declared a nature reserve because it is one of the last unspoiled peat-mosses in Cheshire, indeed there is only one other similar moss in Europe.It consists of a central peat bog on which birch, pine and sallow trees grow. The main body of the moss is sphagnum moss.
